subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] ANNOUNCE: Configuratronic Quikscript Cheat	Sheet
msgSnippet: ... Definitely slashes, as these are conventional notations rather than exact phonetic representations (for which square brackets are used). For example,
messageBody:
Nathan Sharfi scripsit:

> The IPA (and X-SAMPA) values might be contentious; I'm simply going
> off message number [2017][] and the IPA-for-English Wikipedia page as
> best I can; I'm California-born and -raised. Similarly, I'm not sure
> if I should be using brackets, slashes, or nothing at all there.

Definitely slashes, as these are conventional notations rather than
exact phonetic representations (for which square brackets are used).
For example, Australian English uses something like [æʉ] (X-SAMPA [{}]
for the MOUTH vowel, but since this performs the same function as [aɪ] in
mainstream U.K. and North American accents, it can still be notated /aɪ/.

The only discrepancy is the GOAT vowel, which is not conventionally
written /o/. Here there is a split: when notating North American
English, /oʊ/ is used, but when notating British English, where there
is no rounding, /əʊ/ is used instead. So I would write /oʊ ~ əʊ/
instead, "~" being the notation for "or".

--
John Cowan http://www.ccil.org/~cowan <cowan@...>
You tollerday donsk? N. You tolkatiff scowegian? Nn.
You spigotty anglease? Nnn. You phonio saxo? Nnnn.
Clear all so! `Tis a Jute.... (Finnegans Wake 16.5)

> off message number [2017][] and the IPA-for-English Wikipedia page as

> if I should be using brackets, slashes, or nothing at all there.

Definitely slashes, as these are conventional notations rather than
exact phonetic representations (for which square brackets are used).
For example, Australian English uses something like [æʉ] (X-SAMPA [{}]

mainstream U.K. and North American accents, it can still be notated /aɪ/.

The only discrepancy is the GOAT vowel, which is not conventionally
written /o/.  Here there is a split: when notating North American
English, /oʊ/ is used, but when notating British English, where there
is no rounding, /əʊ/ is used instead.  So I would write /oʊ ~ əʊ/
